(7) 
Barometrical <s>Ob<\s> Divisions before y<sup>t<\sup> time, 
the <u>Peterburgh<\u> Barometer was above 30 inches, 
& once above 31, whereas that at <u>Lunden<\u> 
was but a little above 29, & but once at 29c6. 
And indeed through the whole year, the 
<u>Lunden Barometer<\u> I observe was only now 
& then below 28 inches, & much seldomer 
above 30. But I shall perhaps be better a-
ble to give an account of these matters when 
I come to the observations of future years. 
2. As I have taken notice in other places, 
so I find in these Observations, a great con-
formity between the Winds, especially when strong for some time, & when they have been for some time in or near the same 
Quarter. 
3. As for the <u>Weather<\u>, no good judgment 
could be made of it in the space of five 
weeks, w<sup>ch<\sup> is all the time in w<sup>ch<\sup> the Obser
vations tally. Only I take notice that 
Thunder
